evidence_span: Caudal motion segments from six mice returned from a 30-day Bion M1 mission and eight vivarium controls were loaded to failure in four-point bending.

Astronauts experience a 4.3-fold increase in intervertebral disc herniation rate following spaceflight 1 (Figs. 1 and 2).Herniation occurs when the annulus fibrosus or cartilage endplate junction is damaged and nucleus pulposus material ext

Disc herniation can be mechanically induced via a combination of hyper-flexion plus compression, 2,3 making herniation likely during heavy lifting events in a flexed posture.

Spine unloading due to microgravity exposure is thought to cause supraphysiologic disc swelling and hydration, as suggested by the increased spine length during spaceflight 4,5 and disc swelling observed during prolonged bed rest.

7By contrast, gravity loading increases slack in intervertebral ligaments and reduces the disc's resistance to bending; consequently, forward bending stresses are 300% lower in the evening than in the early morning.

9Furthermore, supraphysiologic disc swelling leads to a loss of lumbar lordosis, 10 offsetting tensile and compressive differences between the anterior and posterior annulus and increasing tension in the posterior annulus.

11,12Together, these altered disc biomechanics associated with spaceflight may elevate an astronaut's herniation risk during flexion movements upon return to a gravitational environment.

For example, Bailey et al. observed that uniaxial compressive creep properties decrease in murine caudal discs post-spaceflight 16 and do not recover significantly over 7day re-acclimation to gravity.

18No studies to date have measured changes in mechanical bending properties of the spine following spaceflight.

Given the importance of bending motions for herniation induction, we hypothesized that the biomechanical bending properties of mouse spines following spaceflight are diminished as compared to ground controls.

Eight control mice were kept on the ground during the same 30-day period in standard vivarium cages (GM 500, Tecniplast, Buguggiate, Italy).BSP personnel sacrificed mice and dissected and flash froze tissues.
Specimens were kept hydrated with phosphate buffered saline (PBS) throughout tissue preparation.
Each motion segment was placed in a custom 3D-printed four-point bending device such that the plane of bending coincided with the ventral-dorsal plane (Fig.
3).Four 25-gauge stainless steel needles were inserted through the top and bottom parts of the device, perpendicular to the plane of bending, to create the four contact points.

Beam deflection calculations confirmed a negligible (<10 μm) maximum deflection of the needles during the bending tests, and X-rays taken at incremental bending displacements confirmed no bone-on-bone contact.

Beam deflection calculations confirmed a negligible (<10 μm) maximum deflection of the needles during the bending tests, and X-rays taken at incremental bending displacements confirmed no bone-on-bone contact.

Beam deflection calculations confirmed a negligible (<10 μm) maximum deflection of the needles during the bending tests, and X-rays taken at incremental bending displacements confirmed no bone-on-bone contact.

The lower supports of the bending system were spaced 7.5 mm apart, while the upper supports were spaced 2.5 mm apart and attached to the moving cross-head of a materials test system (ElectroForce 3200; Bose, Eden Prairie, MN).Each specimen

The bending stiffness was defined as the slope of the most linear region, and the bending strength was defined as the maximum load before failure (Fig. 4).Data from the five preconditioning cycles was used to calculate the maximum load reac
Specimens were then decalcified with a mild ion-exchange agent (Biocare Medical; Concord, CA), embedded in paraffin, and cut into 7-μm thick sections.

Residual sections were stained with Safranin O.The intensity of Safranin O staining is directly proportional to the proteoglycan content in cartilage; thus, this method was used to assess relative proteoglycan contents in the growth plates

5).This VOI was chosen rather than isolated epiphyses because murine epiphyses are very small (~0.7-0.8 mm 3 ) and composed largely of cortical bone, which remodels slower than trabecular bone.

16,17Murine caudal discs may not experience the same amount of daily loading as human discs, and thus the change in load in microgravity conditions may not be great enough to cause as much disc swelling as in humans.
However, strain rate was held constant and thus did not contribute to changes in failure location among specimens.
Control specimens tended to fail at the cartilage endplate junction, which is known to be a source of weakness and the most common location of failure causing disc herniation in humans.

For the trabecular VOI adjacent to the growth plate, we found that spaceflight significantly reduced BV/TV, BMD, and trabecular thickness.
The 18% reduction in BMD we measured is comparable to the 7-15% reductions in BMD reported for rat tibias subjected to 23-30 days of hindlimb unloading.

30,31The most significantly reduced parameter in this study was trabecular thickness, which decreased by 14% for the trabecular VOI (p = 0.001) and 9% for the entire vertebra (p = 0.0007), and is consistent with reports of decreased trabecu
31This thinning of trabeculae may help explain the fractures of individual trabeculae that we observed in failed post-flight specimens (Fig.

32Our findings of bone loss following spaceflight agree with various rodent studies showing decreased trabecular bone volume fraction and decreased bone formation resulting in a relative osteopenia following spaceflight.
[33][34]4][35] Bone formation can be inhibited within less than a week of spaceflight, and is correlated with decreased mRNA levels for bone matrix proteins.

For the trabecular VOI, displacement at failure increased with BV/TV and BMD, and bending strength weakly increased with BMD, indicating that BMD may be a reasonably good predictor of failure risk in bending.

Failure at the endplate junction, which accounts for 65% of clinical disc herniation injuries, 19 may be caused by poor structural attachment between the disc and vertebra due to poor bone quality.
Increased disc size in osteoporotic patients may lead to increased risk for herniation by the same mechanism as disc swelling during spaceflight.
41Swelling pressure in bovine discs is similar to human lumbar discs, 42 indicating similar-magnitude compressive loading.
Tails of mice may experience less loading from muscles and passive structures.

Additionally, while murine caudal discs have a similar average aspect ratio (height/diameter) to human lumbar discs (0.23 vs. 0.24, respectively), 41,43 caudal motion segments have a more circular geometry with no posterior elements, which

Aside from geometric differences, rodents differ from humans in that they do not express matrix metalloproteinase-1, 41 which is thought to be involved in bone remodeling and may have differential effects on the amount of bone loss in space

Mouse discs also retain notochordal cells in the nucleus throughout life, which may affect swelling and viscoelastic properties and, in turn, cause rodent discs to respond differently to mechanical loading than those of humans.

Mouse discs also retain notochordal cells in the nucleus throughout life, which may affect swelling and viscoelastic properties and, in turn, cause rodent discs to respond differently to mechanical loading than those of humans.

Mouse discs also retain notochordal cells in the nucleus throughout life, which may affect swelling and viscoelastic properties and, in turn, cause rodent discs to respond differently to mechanical loading than those of humans.
41Lastly, mice are observed to use their tails intermittently to move about inflight enclosures during spaceflight, 16 which in theory may overload the tails and accelerate disc degeneration.
